Decoction of xia ku cao raised ALT and AST values in laboratory mice, indicating potential liver toxicity.

Name: cang zhu

Other name: 蒼朮, 茅朮, 茅蒼朮, 大蒼朮, 生蒼朮, 炒蒼朮, 炒茅朮, 焦蒼朮, 蒼朮炭, 制蒼朮, 米泔水炒蒼朮

Geography: Atractylodes lancea Thunb.: mainly produced in Jiangsu, Hubei, Henan, Anhui provinces of China.
Atractylodes chinensis (DC.) Koidz.: mainly produced in Inner Mongolia, Hebei, Shanxi, Liaoning, Jilin, and Heilongjiang provinces of China.
Maladies Treated: edema with fullness of the abdomen
headaches, body aches, solar plexus pain, pain in extremities due to wind-cold-dampness
headache of women due to deficiency
digestive disorder: indigestion, poor appetite, epigastric fullness
spiritlessness, lack of strength in limbs
retention of damp-phlegm and retained fluid
Medical Function: strengthens the digestion
expels wind-dampness
induces sweating
improves night vision
simmering cang zhu in water to release fragrance can help in getting rid of fungi and bacteria
increase the secretion ions of sodium, potassium and chlorine in the urine
alcohol extract of cang zhu can maintain the lowering of blood sugar of regular rabbits

mixture of the essential oils of β-eudesmol and hinesol possesses a sedative effect on laboratory mice; prolongs sleep using hexobarbital sodium; inhibits spasm caused by electric shock; helps deliver carbon dust in small intestines
anti-ulcer effect: β-eudesmol of cang zhu inhibits secretion of stomach acid and inhibits ulcer
atractylone has an inhibiting effect on HBV (hepatitis B virus)
protects the gastric mucosa
Dosage: 10 to 20 g. Concentrated extract 0.5 to 2 g.
Samples of Formulae:
See yeast infection.
See a report below.
Contraindications:
Not to use in case of yinxu (yin deficient) with heat and/or sweaty with qixu (qi deficient).
Yin deficient with heat, qi deficiency with excessive sweating contraindicated.
Not for patients with internal heat, yin deficiency, blood deficiency, insufficient vital essence, internal heat with tidal fever, dry mouth and lips, coughing with sputum or blood, epistaxis, blocked pharynx, constipation and retention of stool. Not for those with agitation of the liver and kidney qi.
Cautioned for blood deficiency, timidity, and emotional depression (seven emotions qi depression); mistaken use may deplete qi and blood, dry fluids, and aggravate fullness from empty fire.
